reports.suggestion_message:
To solve this problem, you can try the following approaches:


- Some affected dependencies have newer versions available.
You may want to consider updating them to a newer version to see if the issue has been fixed.

ntapi v0.3.7 has the following newer versions available: 0.4.0


- If the issue is not solved by updating the dependencies, a fix has to be
implemented by those dependencies. You can help with that by notifying the
maintainers of this problem (e.g. by creating a bug report) or by proposing a
fix to the maintainers (e.g. by creating a pull request):

  - ntapi@0.3.7
  - Repository: https://github.com/MSxDOS/ntapi
  - Detailed warning command: `cargo report future-incompatibilities --id 153 --package ntapi@0.3.7`

- If waiting for an upstream fix is not an option, you can use the `[patch]`
section in `Cargo.toml` to use your own version of the dependency. For more
information, see:
https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/overriding-dependencies.html#the-patch-section

per_package.ntapi@0.3.7:
The package `ntapi v0.3.7` currently triggers the following future incompatibility lints:
> [0m[1m[38;5;11mwarning[0m[0m[1m[38;5;15m: reference to packed field is unaligned[0m
> [0m    [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m--> [0m[0mC:\Users\Srijan\.cargo\registry\src\github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823\ntapi-0.3.7\src\ntexapi.rs:2783:52[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m|[0m
> [0m[1m[38;5;14m2783[0m[0m [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m|[0m[0m [0m[0m        *tick_count.QuadPart_mut() = read_volatile(&(*USER_SHARED_DATA).u.TickCountQuad);[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m| [0m[0m                                                   [0m[0m[1m[38;5;11m^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m|[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mnote[0m[0m: `#[allow(unaligned_references)]` on by default[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mwarning[0m[0m: this was previously accepted by the compiler but is being phased out; it will become a hard error in a future release![0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mnote[0m[0m: for more information, see issue #82523 <https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/82523>[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mnote[0m[0m: fields of packed structs are not properly aligned, and creating a misaligned reference is undefined behavior (even if that reference is never dereferenced)[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mhelp[0m[0m: copy the field contents to a local variable, or replace the reference with a raw pointer and use `read_unaligned`/`write_unaligned` (loads and stores via `*p` must be properly aligned even when using raw pointers)[0m
> 
> [0m[1m[38;5;11mwarning[0m[0m[1m[38;5;15m: reference to packed field is unaligned[0m
> [0m    [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m--> [0m[0mC:\Users\Srijan\.cargo\registry\src\github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823\ntapi-0.3.7\src\ntexapi.rs:2807:25[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m|[0m
> [0m[1m[38;5;14m2807[0m[0m [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m|[0m[0m [0m[0m        ((read_volatile(&(*USER_SHARED_DATA).u.TickCountQuad)[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m| [0m[0m                        [0m[0m[1m[38;5;11m^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m|[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mnote[0m[0m: `#[allow(unaligned_references)]` on by default[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mwarning[0m[0m: this was previously accepted by the compiler but is being phased out; it will become a hard error in a future release![0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mnote[0m[0m: for more information, see issue #82523 <https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/82523>[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mnote[0m[0m: fields of packed structs are not properly aligned, and creating a misaligned reference is undefined behavior (even if that reference is never dereferenced)[0m
> [0m     [0m[0m[1m[38;5;14m= [0m[0m[1m[38;5;15mhelp[0m[0m: copy the field contents to a local variable, or replace the reference with a raw pointer and use `read_unaligned`/`write_unaligned` (loads and stores via `*p` must be properly aligned even when using raw pointers)[0m
>
